<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[87, 286, 285, 301]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[675, 286, 861, 301]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[87, 365, 374, 380]]<|/det|>
You will need: List of formulae (MF19)  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[87, 397, 217, 412]]<|/det|>
## INSTRUCTIONS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[87, 413, 836, 625]]<|/det|>
INSTRUCTIONS- Answer all questions.- Use a black or dark blue pen. You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.- Write your name, centre number and candidate number in the boxes at the top of the page.- Write your answer to each question in the space provided.- Do not use an erasable pen or correction fluid.- Do not write on any bar codes.- If additional space is needed, you should use the lined page at the end of this booklet; the question number or numbers must be clearly shown.- You should use a calculator where appropriate.- You must show all necessary working clearly; no marks will be given for unsupported answers from a calculator.- Give non- exact numerical answers correct to 3 significant figures, or 1 decimal place for angles in degrees, unless a different level of accuracy is specified in the question.- Where a numerical value for the acceleration due to gravity \((g)\) is needed, use \(10 \text{ms}^{- 2}\) .  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[87, 650, 208, 664]]<|/det|>
## INFORMATION  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[87, 665, 693, 695]]<|/det|>
INFORMATION- The total mark for this paper is 50.- The number of marks for each question or part question is shown in brackets [ ].

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[74, 68, 87, 85]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[312, 84, 640, 255]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 270, 876, 338]]<|/det|>
A particle \(P\) is attached to one end of a light inextensible string of length \(a\). The other end of the string is attached to a fixed point \(O\). The particle \(P\) is held with the string taut and making an angle \(\theta\) with the downward vertical. The particle \(P\) is then projected with speed \(\frac{4}{5}\sqrt{5ag}\) perpendicular to the string and just completes a vertical circle (see diagram).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 348, 288, 365]]<|/det|>
Find the value of \(\cos \theta\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[848, 348, 876, 365]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[72, 69, 89, 87]]<|/det|>
<label>5</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 69, 875, 117]]<|/det|>
A particle \(P\) is projected with speed \(u\) at an angle \(\alpha\) above the horizontal from a point \(O\) on a horizontal plane and moves freely under gravity. The horizontal and vertical displacements of \(P\) from \(O\) at a subsequent time \(t\) are denoted by \(x\) and \(y\) respectively.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[109, 127, 139, 144]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 127, 544, 144]]<|/det|>
Derive the equation of the trajectory of \(P\) in the form

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[384, 151, 568, 180]]<|/det|>
\[y = x\tan \alpha -\frac{gx^2}{2u^2}\sec^2\alpha .\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[848, 155, 876, 174]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 636, 715, 655]]<|/det|>
The point \(Q\) is the highest point on the trajectory of \(P\) in the case where \(\alpha = 45^{\circ}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[72, 68, 89, 85]]<|/det|>
<label>6</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 67, 875, 117]]<|/det|>
Two smooth spheres \(A\) and \(B\) have equal radii and masses \(m\) and \(2m\) respectively. Sphere \(B\) is at rest on a smooth horizontal floor. Sphere \(A\) is moving on the floor with velocity \(u\) and collides directly with \(B\). The coefficient of restitution between the spheres is \(e\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[109, 127, 138, 144]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[146, 126, 662, 144]]<|/det|>
Find, in terms of \(u\) and \(e\), the velocities of \(A\) and \(B\) after the collision.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[848, 127, 876, 144]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[146, 160, 875, 180]]<|/det|>
<form>......

<form>......

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 450, 875, 485]]<|/det|>
Subsequently, \(B\) collides with a fixed vertical wall which makes an angle \(\theta\) with the direction of motion of \(B\), where \(\tan \theta = \frac{3}{4}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 496, 875, 532]]<|/det|>
The coefficient of restitution between \(B\) and the wall is \(\frac{2}{3}\). Immediately after \(B\) collides with the wall, the kinetic energy of \(A\) is \(\frac{5}{32}\) of the kinetic energy of \(B\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[109, 543, 139, 562]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[146, 543, 368, 562]]<|/det|>
Find the possible values of \(e\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[146, 72, 875, 104]]<|/det|>
Show that \(x\) and \(t\) are related by the equation \(\mathrm{e}^{-40t} = (2x - 1)\mathrm{e}^{2x - 2}\) and deduce what happens to \(x\) as \(t\) becomes large.
